properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Time span: midday Tuesday until Wednesday morning. Location: Labrador Straits. Remarks: Snow will begin around midday Tuesday then ease briefly near midnight Tuesday night before a second, less extensive, round of snow begins overnight. The snow will taper off Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-19T19:57:15-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant period of freezing rain expected. Freezing rain amounts: 5 to 15 mm. Locations: Green Bay - White Bay, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Buchans and the interior, and inland areas of the west coast from Gros Morne National Park to Corner Brook. Time span: continuing until early this afternoon. Remarks: The freezing rain will change to rain near noon over all areas except through Green Bay - White Bay where it will become a mix of rain and snow. Areas near White Bay could see up to 5 cm of snow this afternoon. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-19T18:19:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-19T14:21:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0603174313.2019
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Buchans and the interior, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard beginning late overnight and lasting most of Wednesday. A low pressure system currently in northern Manitoba will move into southwestern Hudson Bay this evening and intensify tonight and Wednesday as it tracks slowly northeastward. Snow which has already moved into Arviat will become heavier throughout the day today, while northeast winds will strengthen tonight. The worst conditions will be late overnight and Wednesday morning with near zero visibility in snow and blowing snow. The snow will gradually taper off later on Wednesday allowing visibilities to slowly improve during the late afternoon or evening. Total snowfalls of 15 to 20 cm are likely. Rankin Inlet and Chesterfield Inlet will also be impacted by this system, although at this point it appears that the worst conditions will be at Arviat. Please listen for updated watches and warnings as this system moves into the area. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-20T01:29:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-19T09:30:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3967948426.2019
Area: Arviat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River From Gardenton To Stuartburn
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Stuartburn due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-19T16:30:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-18T15:20:27-06:00, EAFB9C7B-DD9C-87D8-3EB4-DA7DF0BCF381
Area: Roseau River from Gardenton to Stuartburn
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of dense fog are expected tonight into Tuesday morning. Fog has developed this evening over some areas including the higher terrain of the Dundalk Highlands. Fog will continue to develop across much of southwestern Ontario tonight persisting into Tuesday morning. Additionally there is a risk of freezing drizzle overnight into Tuesday morning. Untreated surfaces may become slippery. Conditions will improve through the morning Tuesday. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-19T19:39:24-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant wintry weather is expected. Locations: central, western and southwestern Newfoundland. Time Span: Thursday morning to Friday afternoon. Remarks: A developing storm is forecast to bring wintry weather to the island later this week. While it is too soon to provide specific details, the potential exists for a prolonged wet, heavy snowfall event with gusty northeasterly winds. The snow will likely be heaviest inland with significant accumulations possible. Over coastal areas, precipitation is expected to occur as a mixture of snow and rain. Additional information will be provided as the details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-19T19:56:49-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure system tracking across the northern United States will spread snow into southwestern Saskatchewan this afternoon. Snow at times heavy tonight will taper off to light by morning as the system moves toward the Dakotas. Total accumulations of 10 to 15 cm are likely over much of the Shaunavon and Assiniboia regions with slightly lesser amounts toward Estevan and Carlyle. Snowfall amounts will diminish quickly to the north of the Trans-Canada Highway. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-20T02:34:35-00:00

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Areas of dense fog are occurring across some areas this morning. Patchy freezing drizzle is also possible. With temperatures hovering near the freezing mark, icy patches on roads and walkways may be possible. Fog will slowly dissipate through the morning. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A strong frontal system will move into Alaska today and reach the northern Yukon tonight. Snow will begin later this afternoon and as the system nears, winds of 70 km/h are forecast to develop. The snow and wind will combine to produce blizzard conditions tonight. The blizzard will end by early Wednesday morning when winds ease. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-20T05:00:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-19T13:01:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1233834889.2019
Area: Dempster

properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure system moving into Alberta will give snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 centimetres for parts of the province on Tuesday. Snow has begun in the Calgary area and will spread eastward this morning. Snow will taper off early Wednesday morning as the system moves into Saskatchewan. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant wintry weather is expected later this week. Possible Snowfall: 15 to 25 cm Locations: inland portions of most of Newfoundland. Time Span: Thursday morning to Friday afternoon. Remarks: A developing storm is forecast to bring wintry weather to the Island later this week. At this time it appears much of Newfoundland's interior will see a prolonged wet, heavy snowfall event with gusty northeasterly winds. The highest snowfall accumulations should be in the Island's interior, with more of a mixture of snow and rain the closer you get to the coast. Along Newfoundland's east coast, precipitation will fall mostly as rain. Some uncertainty still remains with this system, updates will be provided as the scenario becomes more clear. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Areas of dense fog are occurring across some areas this morning. Patchy freezing drizzle is also possible. With temperatures hovering near the freezing mark, icy patches on roads and walkways may be possible. Fog will slowly dissipate through the morning. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-19T18:11:43-00:00
